summary: The U.S. District Court for the Central District of California today entered a final judgment against California's Department of Labor (DOL) for failing to comply with the federal timeliness requirements for the state's unemployment insurance program.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Sacramento, California, DOL and the Department of Health and Human Services (DHS) failed to provide timely and effective relief to thousands of unemployed California workers who sought to participate in the federal program. The complaint alleges that DOL failed to meet its obligations under Section 14110.7 of the Social Security Act and Rule 14b-5 thereunder, and failed to timely and effectively respond to their requests for relief.  The complaint further alleges that the DOL's failure to respond to requests for assistance in this matter was a direct result of underfunding by the state.  In its judgment, the court found that the state was in "substantial compliance" with Section 1410.7, and that it could not afford to delay the issuance of a writ of mandate. The court also ruled that the amount of relief sought by DOL was insufficient to justify the delay in issuing the writ of mandamus.  DOL has agreed to settle the case without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint. The settlement is subject to court approval. The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by John Rymas of the Chicago Regional Office, and the litigation will be led by Eric R. Werner. The case is being supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay. The examination that led to the investigation was conducted by Jennifer C. Barry of the Boston Regional Office and supervised by Marc Blau of the Division of Economic and Risk Analysis. The litigation is being led by Ms. Barry and Ms. B. Barry.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the California Secretary of State's Office and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Â The SEC's Office of Inspector General has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment in an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.  Investors can quickly and easily check the backgrounds of people selling investments by using theÂ SEC's investor.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals and whether they have any background in the field. The Office of Compliance has also issued an Investor Alert about the dangers of overspending on administrative items, including the purchase of a home and car, and an accounting of how many people are eligible to apply for unemployment benefits.
